Another pro is that there's a culture of candid feedback amongst management that helps you grow and learn, not wondering how you are doing.
cons: One of the cons of Amazon is that they are very frugal, this means projects that should have more staffing are typically running leaner than they should. While this benefits the customer because it ensures a scrutinized prioritization of work, it can lead to some overwork from the employees. The planning cycle has the effect of needing a lot data, projects, and documents to be delivered at one point in the year which can lead to some artificial stress induced by these dates. While the cycle is effective, there is a price paid for it.

pros: They welcome suggestions for improvements (most of the time), TONS of employee resources, if you are willing & able to sweat and learn and be flexible/open to performing various tasks there's a lot to feel useful for. Mistakes are fine! As long as you learn from them, meet quality requirements (and if they aren't easy to understand, ask for examples and clarifications), are always improving in some small way, and are at least faster than the slowest person in your center, a mistake here or there is expected - no one's perfect, and Amazon has designed systems to handle them.
cons:
There are a LOT of systems, and many of them seem like they're always changing (so if you want to learn something once & never again, don't recommend Amazon for you). Upper management moves & shuffles so frequently that it's tough to feel supported when you have questions or difficulty (who do I ask now? etc). If something is wrong or you have a problem - stretched too far and pulled a muscle, misplaced a work tool, can't find your station, etc - no one is gonna come ask if you're ok (with rare exceptions), you have to speak up and ask for help yourself. A bit of a "duh", perhaps, but my previous job/life experiences didn't help me here, sitting around & waiting to be rescued will not work here - just make the best decision you can with the information in front of you (or make sure you know who to ask when you need more info). 

Oh, and some folks make a LOT of assumptions about your skills/knowledge based on where they find you & what you're doing. If you haven't been trained in a process or a specific tool/part of the building and someone asks you to do something unfamiliar, say, "Sorry, I haven't been trained in ___ yet." Sometimes they move too fast trying to fill jobs/roles and rely on associates to accurately relay their skills/knowledge rather than checking official training records.

Company policy sometimes makes keeping up with work difficult, for example floors can only have 2 water spiders maximum and even if we say we need more help company policy says we cannot grab another waterspider. This once led to stations being out of work for 45 minutes as 2 water spiders were responsible for almost 40 stowers. If we had had 2 or even 1 more water spider this would not have been a problem, but it was not allowed. Not enough restrooms in the warehouse for the amount of employees we have, outside of break rooms there are around 4 per floor each with 1-2 stalls leading to long wait times. Spend too long waiting effects and it effects your takt time leading to productivity concerns and writeups.
